Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Genetic Dissection of Developmental Evolution in a Poecilogonous Polychaete
Award.AbstractNarration: The spectacular diversity we observe among animals extends to their earliest developmental stages, including eggs, embryos, and larvae. The molecular and genetic mechanisms that give rise to this developmental diversity are poorly understood and have been difficult to study. This project is building tools to facilitate genetic analysis of developmental variation in a marine worm, Streblospio benedicti, whose unique attributes make it ideal for addressing developmental diversity. These animals, which are abundant in intertidal and subtidal mud along the Atlantic and Pacific coasts of the United States, are all very similar as adults but exhibit two very different modes of development. Individuals with different developmental modes are nevertheless capable of interbreeding, allowing for the genetic analysis of their eggs, embryos, and larvae. A freely accessible panel of genetically recombinant strains of S. benedicti, complemented by its genome sequence and genetic map, will enable researchers to discover the molecular mechanisms responsible for variation in animal development. These studies address many longstanding questions about the evolutionary origins of animal diversity, questions that have previously been out of reach of experimental investigations. The genomic tools will also fuel further research into the molecular and cellular biology of a poorly studied group of organisms, and methods for experimental manipulation of these animals will be developed. The research is coupled to the creation of an undergraduate course devoted to building knowledge of animal diversity, and high-school teachers and teachers-in-training will participate in the laboratory research to further national goals of specialized disciplinary expertise for STEM educators.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The earliest stages of an animal's development are guided by interactions between the organism's genome and the structure of the egg cell created by its mother. Understanding how organisms adapt to their environments requires a consideration of these interactions between the maternal and offspring genomes during early development.

 

In this project we developed new methods, resources, and experimental findings to understand genetic variation in early development. The key feature of this work is the study species, the marine worm Streblospio benedicti. Unique among animals, S. benedicti exhibits dramatic heritable variation in its early development. Some females make large eggs that develop directly into juveniles, and others make small eggs that develop into planktonic larvae. This dichotomy is common in animal phylogeny, and our studies provide insight into its quantitative- and population-genetic and genomic basis.

 

We used experimental genetics to discover the factors contributing to differences between the large, directly developing larvae (lecithotrophs) and the small, indirectly-developing larvae (planktotrophs) in S. benedicti. By tracking traits and genotypes across three generations, we were able to determine that larval size and larval anatomy are determined by independent sets of genetic variants. Moreover, although these variants have large individual effects, there are several of them for each trait. This pattern of inheritance was not expected, because it guarantees that hybrids will have intermediate trait values and trait combinations that are never observed in the wild.

 

Our population genomic analyses confirmed that lecithotrophs and planktotrophs are part of a single species with ongoing gene flow, implying that the absence of intermediates in nature results from strong selection against hybrids. We therefore built mathematical models of selection on larval development and found that the models were consistent with selection against intermediates. However, the specific mode of inheritance we observe, with egg size determined by a small number of genes acting in the mother and larval anatomy determined by a small number of independent genes acting in the larva, generates a lot of unfit intermediates when populations meet and hybridize.

 

A major finding of this work is that the architecture of genetic variation in early development in S. benedicti shapes the way that early development can evolve. Because intermediates are maladapted, selection acts to preserve the locally most-common combination of maternal-effect and larval genes. This phenomenon of positive frequency dependence (common genes are favored) counteracts selection for local adaptation.

 

As part of this work, multiple undergraduate students gained field and laboratory research experience, including several independent research projects. The project trained a masters student and provided support for a postdoctoral researcher who will use this work as the foundation for research in her own independent research laboratory. As part of the project, several high school teachers-in-training performed summer internships to gain hands-on research experience. Finally, the work facilitated the creation of a new laboratory course in zoology for NYU undergraduates.
